name: nytimes
text:
Subway ridership is way down in New York City — 20% of the city’s 5.5 million weekday riders are using the system. Many fear the confined spaces of subway cars will lead to coronavirus infections. 

We looked at how safe the air is on the subway. 
https://t.co/PAtFVYsKQn

name: nytimes
text:
Air flow is key in preventing the spread of the virus on subways, along with masks and social distancing. 

The sub… https://t.co/XV9HutseEd

name: nytimes
text:
75% of the air in a subway car is recycled. It’s sucked into vents, cooled and filtered.

25% is pulled from the ou… https://t.co/U0rHO7jLVC

name: nytimes
text:
The ventilation helps fully replace air in the car with outside air about every 3 or 4 minutes.

Filters work to block viral particles, but some could slip past and get dispersed into trains.
https://t.co/PAtFVYsKQn https://t.co/Sygm453p3T

name: nytimes
text: If viral particles slip past the system’s filters, they could circulate at least 3 times in the car over several mi… https://t.co/rH4KYWzB72

name: nytimes
text:
The ventilation system pushes air across the train rather than down into floor vents. So someone standing between a person without a mask who sneezes or coughs and the ceiling vent could come into contact with aerosols. 
https://t.co/PAtFVYsKQn https://t.co/KlOVpYrkQQ

name: nytimes
text:
Experts say that the high air exchange rate and wearing masks sharply reduce the risk of spreading the virus.

But if more people are riding the subway, it's harder for ventilation to lessen the risk of transmission.

See more. 

https://t.co/PAtFVYsKQn
